choices.text: Bjerrum Scotoma
Seidel Scotoma
Double Arcuate Scotoma
Paracentral Scotoma

questions.text: Identify the Field Defect.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bjerrum Scotoma

 

Option A: 

 

Bjerrum scotoma is a localized visual field defect in the shape of an arc or a scotoma that lies between 10 and 20 degrees from the fixation point. It is associated with glaucomatous damage, and a Bjerrum scotoma can be considered a form of arcuate scotoma.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Seidel scotoma: Paracentral scotoma joins blind spot to form sickle shaped scotoma

 

Option C. Double arcuate scotoma: This refers to a scenario where there are Two Arcuate Scotomas in the Same Eye, which could occur in Advanced Glaucoma.

 

Option D. Paracentral scotoma: These are Small, Round, or Oval areas of visual Field Loss that occur near the Center of the visual field but do not arch around the central vision like Arcuate Scotomas do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify a Superior Arcuate Scotoma as a Bjerrum Scotoma, which is a characteristic Visual Field Defect arcing around the Central Vision, typically associated with Glaucomatous Damage.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 232

choices.text:
A. Nasal Shift of Vessels   
B. Bayonetting

A. Temporal Shift of Vessels  
B. Bayoneting

A. Bayoneting   
B. Laminar Dot Sign

A. Bayoneting   
B. Baring of Circum Linear Vessels

questions.text: What are the Glaucomatous changes shown in the below figures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A Nasal Shift of Vessels   B. Bayonetting

 

These are the Optic Disc changes seen in Glaucoma.

 

Optic Disc changes in Glaucoma

 

  • Cupping- Excavation of the Cup
  • Thinning of Neuro Retinal Rim
  • Nasal Shifting of vessels
  • Bayonetting- appearance of vessel being broken off at the margin
  • Laminar Dot Sign- visible pores in Lamina Cribrosa
  • Pulsation of Retinal Arterioles

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that Nasal Shifting of Blood Vessels and Bayonetting, which are indicative of Nerve Fiber Layer Loss, are hallmark signs of Glaucomatous Optic Neuropathy observable upon examination of the Optic Disc.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 231

choices.text: Drance Haemorrhage
Flame Shaped Haemorrhage
Bayonetting
Notching of Rim

questions.text: Identify the sign given below.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Drance Haemorrhage

 

Option A: Drance/ Splinter Haemorrhage:

 

  • Perpendicular to the Optic Disc Margin. Mostly in the Inferotemporal and Superotemporal Regions.
  • Classically these Haemorrhages are located in the Prelaminar Optic Disc, cross the Peripapillary Zone, and extend into the adjacent Superficial Retinal Nerve Fibre Layer.
  • They are a risk factor for progression of Glaucoma. Most common in normal tension glaucoma.
  • Associated with notching of the Neuroretinal Rim or Retinal Nerve Fibre Layer Defects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Flame-Shaped Haemorrhage: Superficial (Nerve Fibre Layer) Haemorrhages in the retina seen in Grade 3 of hypertensive retinopathy, Non-Ischaemic CRVO and few other conditions.


 

Option C. Bayonetting: A sharp turn taken by retinal vessels giving the appearance of being broken off at the margin of the cup due to the erosion of neuroretinal rim. Seen in glaucoma.

 

 

Option D. Notching of Rim: The Neuro-Retinal Rim (the orange-pink tissue between the outer edge of the cup and optic disc margin) becomes thinner. In particular, the rim superotemporally and inferortemporally may develop a notch. Seen in glaucoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drance/Splinter haemorrhages are located in the prelaminar optic disc, cross the peripapillary zone, and extend into the adjacent superficial retinal nerve fibre layer.

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, Page 317

choices.text: 0.3-0.4
0.5-0.6
0.6-0.7
0.7-0.8

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient visits an Ophthalmology clinic for a Routine Eye Examination. The patient has a family history of Glaucoma, so the doctor assesses the patient's Optic Nerve head using Ophthalmoscopy and concludes that the Cup/Disc Ratio is normal. What is the Normal Cup/Disc Ratio?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.3-0.4

 

Option A:

 

  • Cup/Disc Ratio indicates the diameter of the cup expressed as a fraction of the diameter of the disc. Normal C/D ratio is 0.3-0.4.
  • Asymmetry of 0.2 or more between the 2 eyes should be regarded with suspicion for glaucoma and warrants further evaluation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B & C: CDR In the range of 05:1 to 0.7:1 may at times be physiological cupping as seen in patients with large discs. It may also be Glaucomatous.

 

Option D: CDR 0.7-0.8:1 is usually indicative of glaucomatous changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal Cup: Disc Ratio is 0.3-0.4:1.


Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 231; Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, Page 316

choices.text: Schiotz Tonometer
Goldmann Tonometer
Perkins Tonometer
Tonopen

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of Applanation Tonometer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schiotz Tonometer

 

Option A:

 

  • Schiotz Tonometer is a type of indentation tonometer.
  • SCHIOTz: SCleral rigidity Hampers IOT measurement
  • Applanation tonometry is based on Imbert-Fick principle according to which pressure inside a sphere (P) is equal to the force required to flatten its surface (F) divided by the Area of flattening (A).
  • Measurement of IOP:
    • Directly: Manometry
    • Indirectly: Tonometry

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Goldmann tonometer: This is the most widely used type of applanation tonometer. It measures IOP by flattening a small, known area of the cornea. The force required to flatten this area correlates with the IOP. It's considered the gold standard for IOP measurement.

 

 

Option C. Perkins tonometer is a portable version of the Goldmann tonometer, using the same principle of applanation. It's particularly useful for bedridden patients or those who cannot sit at a slit lamp where a Goldmann tonometer is typically used.

 

 

Option D. Tonopen involves both applanation and indentation processes. It is a small, handheld, battery-powered portable device. The tonometer has an applanating footplate with a tiny plunger protruding minimally from the center. As the tonometer makes contact with the eye, the plunger receives resistance from the cornea and the IOP producing a record of rising force by a strain gauge. At the moment of applanation, the force is shared by the foot plate and the plunger resulting in a momentary small decrease from the steadily increasing force. This is the point of applanation which is recorded electronically. Multiple readings are averaged. Because the area of applanation is known, the IOP can then be calculated. The readings correlate well with Goldmann tonometry within normal IOP ranges.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the Schiotz tonometer is not an example of applanation tonometer. The Schiotz tonometer is an indentation tonometer

 

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 510

choices.text: Schiotz Tonometer
Goldmann Tonometer
Perkins Tonometer
Manometer

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Option A:

 

  • The image is of Schiotz tonometer – an indentation tonometer.

 

Used to measure intraocular pressure

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Gold mann tonometer: GOLD standard

 

 

Option C. Perkins tonometer: Perkin: Portable

Preferred in children.

 

Mnemonic: PERK chocolate is preferred by children.

 

 

Option D: Manometer-

 

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th edition, page 510

choices.text: 2.3 microlit/min
2.1 microlit/min
1.5 microlit/min
1.9 microlit/min

questions.text: The Normal Aqueous production Rate is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2.3 microlit/min

 

Educational Objective-

 

Aqueous humour is produced from plasma by the epithelium of ciliary body pars plicata, via active and passive secretion at a rate of 2.3 microlit/min.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 219

choices.text: Uveoscleral Drainage
Via the Iris
Trabecular Outflow
A & B Together

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of chronic open-angle glaucoma presents with gradually increasing blurring of vision and frequent headaches. Examination reveals signs of aqueous outflow obstruction. 90% of aqueous humour exits the eye via which route?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trabecular Outflow

 

Option C: Trabecular Outflow (90%): Aqueous flows through the trabeculae into the schlemm canal and then the episcleral veins.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Uveoscleral Drainage (10%): Aqueous passes across the face of the ciliary body into the suprachoroidal space and is drained by the venous circulation in the ciliary body, choroid and sclera.

 

Option B: Iris: some amount of aqueous drains via the iris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

90% of aqueous out flows through the trabeculae of the trabecular meshwork into the schlemm canal and then the episcleral veins.

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th edition, page 306

choices.text: Pseudoexfoliation
Sampaolesi Line
Glaukomflecken
Krukenberg Spindle

questions.text: Identify the sign.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Krukenberg Spindle

 

Option D:

 

  • Pigment dispersion syndrome & Pigmentary glaucoma are characterized by the liberation of pigment granules from iris pigment epithelium, and their deposition throughout the anterior segment.
  • In this, pigment is deposited on the endothelium in a vertical spindle shape.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudo-Exfoliation: The anterior lens capsule commonly exhibits a central disc with a peripheral layer of pseudoexfoliative material that shows radial indentations. These two components are separated by a clear zone, which is maintained through abrasion caused by the movement of the pupil.

 

 

Option B. Sampaolesi Line: Refers to pigment deposits that can be observed on or anterior to the Schwalbe's line, particularly in heavily pigmented angles like seen in Pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

 

 

Option C. Glaukomflecken: Refers to small, focal areas of anterior grey-white subcapsular or capsular opacities that develop within the pupillary area. These opacities are considered pathognomonic of previous episodes of acute congestive angle closure and represent focal infarcts of the lens epithelium.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deposition of pigments on the endothelium of cornea in a spindle shaped central vertical orientation is called Krukenberg Spindle.

 

Ref: Kanskis Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, Page 368 & 370

choices.text: 0.10 ml
0.50 ml
0.25 ml
1.0 ml

questions.text: What is the Amount of Aqueous Humour in the Anterior Chamber?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.25 ml

 

Educational Objective:

 

The amount of aqueous humour in the anterior chamber is 0.25 ml & posterior chamber is 0.06ml.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 221

choices.text: a – i, b – ii, c – iii, d – iv
a – iii, b – i, c – iv, d - ii
a – i, b – iv, c – iii, d - ii
a – iii, b – i, c – ii, d - iv

questions.text: Match the following instruments according to their category.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a – iii, b – i, c – iv, d – ii

 

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th edition, page 308-312

choices.text: Corneal thickness with Peripheral Anterior Chamber depth
Central & Peripheral Corneal Thickness
Central & Peripheral Anterior Chamber Depth
Central Anterior Chamber Depth & Iris Illumination

questions.text: Van Herrick Grading for Angle of Anterior Chamber compares?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corneal Thickness with Peripheral Anterior Chamber Depth

 

Explanation:

 

  • The Van Herrick grading for angle of AC represents the Limbal AC depth in terms of corneal thickness. Thus, more the depth, greater is the angle and grading, suggestive of a widely opened angle.

 

Van Herrick grading

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Van Herrick’s grading is the clinical method of assessment of anterior chamber depth by comparing the depth of peripheral anterior chamber to that of the corneal thickness as seen on slit lamp examination. It is useful in identifying cases with potential of angle closure.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 242

choices.text: Schwalbe Line
Ciliary Body Band
Scleral Spur
Schlemm Canal

questions.text: The peripheral termination of Descemet Membrane is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schwalbe Line

 

Option A:

 

  • Schwalbe Line is the most anterior structure, appearing whitish to variably pigmented.
  • Anatomically it demarcates the peripheral termination of Descemet membrane and the anterior limit of the trabeculae.
  • There may be pigment deposits on or anterior to the Schwalbe line known as Sampaolesi line – especially in heavily pigmented angles. (e.g. pseudo exfoliation syndrome)
  • Structures visualized on Gonioscopy:
  1. Schwalbe’s line
  2. Trabecular meshwork
  3. Scleral spur
  4. Ciliary body band

 

(Mnemonic: Silly Tigers, Strong Cats)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ciliary Body Band is part of the ciliary body that is visible when viewing the anterior chamber angle through gonioscopy.

 

Option C. Scleral Spur is a projection of the sclera that can be seen during gonioscopy. It provides attachment for the trabecular meshwork and the ciliary muscle.

 

Option D. Schlemm's Canal is a circular channel in the eye that collects aqueous humor from the anterior chamber and delivers it into the bloodstream.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwalbe's line represents the peripheral termination of Descemet's membrane.

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, Page 313

choices.text: False Low IOP
Normal IOP
False High IOP
Not able to measure IOP

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient who had -6D of Myopia, has come for follow up 1 week post LASIK surgery. On measuring her IOP by Goldmann Applanation Tonometry, what do you expect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) False Low IOP

 

Explanation:

 

  • By reshaping the cornea to induce a more favorable refraction, refractive surgery alters the cornea’s biomechanical properties.
  • These changes include:
    • Decrease in Corneal Hysteresis
    • Flattening of the Corneal Curvature
    • Decrease in the Central Corneal Thickness (CCT)
    • Decrease in Central Corneal Thickness can show False Low IOP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corneal stromal ablation in LASIK reduces stromal thickness leading to false low IOP measurement.

 

Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Tonometry_after_Refractive_Surgery

choices.text: Ciliary Zonules
Ciliary Body
Iris
Trabecular Meshwork

questions.text: What is the site of Aqueous Humour production?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ciliary body

 

Option B: Ciliary body pars plicata is the site of aqueous production.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ciliary Zonules, also known as the zonular fibers, they are responsible for holding the crystalline lens in place and do not play a direct role in the production of aqueous humor.

 

Option C. Iris is not involved in the production of aqueous humor.

 

Option D. The trabecular meshwork is involved in the drainage of aqueous humor from the eye, not its production. It acts as a filter for the aqueous humor as it flows out of the anterior chamber, eventually leading to Schlemm's canal and then into the systemic circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The aqueous humor is produced by the ciliary body, specifically by the ciliary epithelium. This production is essential for maintaining the eye's intraocular pressure and providing metabolic support to the eye's internal structures.

 

Ref: pg 72/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

choices.text: Trabecular Meshwork
Schlemm’s Canal
Episcleral Veins
Corneal Endothelium

questions.text: The Drainage pathway of Aqueous Humour does not include:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corneal Endothelium

 

Option D: The corneal endothelium is responsible for maintaining corneal clarity by regulating fluid and solute transport between the cornea and the aqueous humor. However, it is not a part of the aqueous humor drainage pathway. Its primary function is to keep the cornea dehydrated and transparent, not to facilitate the outflow of aqueous humor.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The trabecular meshwork is a key component of the conventional (or main) aqueous humor drainage pathway, located at the angle of the anterior chamber, which acts as a filter for the aqueous humor flowing out of the eye.

 

Option B. Schlemm's canal is directly linked to the trabecular meshwork. It collects aqueous humor from the trabecular meshwork and plays a crucial role in the drainage process.

 

Option C. The aqueous humor, after passing through Schlemm's canal, eventually drains into the episcleral veins. These veins are part of the conventional aqueous humor drainage pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The aqueous humor drainage pathway primarily involves the trabecular meshwork, Schlemm's canal, and the episcleral veins. The corneal endothelium, while important for maintaining corneal clarity, is not part of this drainage pathway.

 

Ref: Pg 76/Anatomy and Physiology of Eye/AK KHURANA/3rd Edition

choices.text: Ultrafiltration
Secretion
Diffusion
All the above

questions.text: The Mechanism involved in Aqueous Humour formation include:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D. Considering that ultrafiltration, secretion, and diffusion all play a role, albeit to varying extents, in the formation of aqueous humor, this option is correct. Secretion is the most significant mechanism, but ultrafiltration and diffusion also contribute to the process.

 

The Aqueous Humour is primarily derived from plasma within the capillary network

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ultra-Filtration is a passive process where fluid is forced through a membrane by hydrostatic pressure. In the context of aqueous humor production, some component of the fluid is formed by ultrafiltration from the capillaries in the ciliary body.

 

Option B. Secretion is the primary mechanism involved in the production of aqueous humor. It is an active process mediated by the ciliary epithelium, which involves the transport of ions, nutrients, and fluids from the ciliary body into the posterior chamber, leading to the formation of aqueous humor.

 

Option C. Diffusion is a passive process of movement of molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aqueous humor formation is a complex process that involves ultra-filtration, secretion, and diffusion. Secretion, primarily from the ciliary epithelium, is the dominant mechanism, but ultra-filtration and diffusion also contribute to the formation of this vital fluid in the eye.

 

REF: Pg 80/Anatomy and Physiology of Eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd Edition

choices.text: Arterial Blood Pressure
Refractive Error
General Anaesthesia
Diurnal Variation

questions.text: The following factors cause Short Term changes in Intraocular Pressure except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Refractive Error

 

Option B: The factors affecting intraocular pressure include:

 

Long Term:   

 

  • Heredity
  • Age
  • Sex
  • Race

 

Short Term:

 

  • Arterial blood pressure
  • Systemic venous pressure
  • Blood pH
  • Diurnal variation
  • Gen. anaesthesia
  • Drugs
  • Plasma osmolarity

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Arterial blood pressure: Changes in arterial blood pressure can indeed influence IOP. An increase in systemic blood pressure can lead to a temporary increase in IOP due to increased blood flow to the eye.

 

Option C. General anesthesia can cause fluctuations in IOP. Certain anesthetic agents and the process of intubation can lead to transient changes in IOP.

 

Option D. Diurnal variation refers to changes in IOP throughout the day. IOP is not constant and can fluctuate based on various factors, including circadian rhythms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While arterial blood pressure, general anesthesia, and diurnal variation can cause short-term fluctuations in intraocular pressure, refractive error does not typically influence these short-term changes.

 

Ref: Pg 92/ Anatomy and Physiology of Eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd Edition

choices.text: Albumin – Globulin Ratio is reversed
Water constitutes only 20% of Aqueous Humour.
Prostaglandins are absent.
The Protein Concentration is less than that of Blood Plasma

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the biochemical composition of aqueous humour:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The Protein Concentration is less than that of Blood Plasma

 

Option D. This is true. The aqueous humor has a much lower protein concentration compared to blood plasma. This low protein content is one of the factors that contribute to its clarity and the ability to transmit light effectively to the retina.

 

Biochemical composition of Aqueous Humour:

 

  • Water 90%
  • Proteins (Less compared to plasma due to blood aqueous barrier)
  • IgG & IgM
  • Amino Acids
  • Dissolved Salts
  • Prostaglandins
  • Inulin & Steroids

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Albumin – globulin ratio is reversed: Normal aqueous humour and the aqueous humour of patients with cataract is virtually protein-free. Patients having retinoblastoma and non-malignant post-inflammatory lesions show significantly high quantities of proteins in the aqueous humour. Retinoblastoma is associated with an increase in the globulin content and an albumin/globulin ratio below unity, while non-malignant post-inflammatory intraocular conditions show a rise of the albumin fraction with an albumin/globulin ratio above unity.

 

Option B. Water constitutes only 20% of aqueous humour: This statement is incorrect. The aqueous humor is predominantly made up of water, constituting more than 90% of its composition. The rest is made up of salts, proteins, and other substances in very small quantities.

 

Option C. Prostaglandins are absent: Prostaglandins can be present in the aqueous humor, though usually in very low concentrations. They play a role in various physiological and pathological processes in the eye, including the regulation of intraocular pressure and inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The aqueous humor has a significantly lower protein concentration than blood plasma, contributing to its clarity and the efficient transmission of light to the retina.

 

Ref: pg 77/ / Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA; Dias PL. Post-inflammatory and malignant protein patterns in aqueous humour. Br J Ophthalmol. 1979 Mar; 63 (3):161-4. doi: 10.1136/bjo.63.3.161. PMID: 435425; PMCID: PMC1043432.

choices.text: Contains Aqueous
Contains Red Cells
Is lined by Endothelium
Contains Partitions

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Schlemm’s Canal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contains Red Cells

 

Option B: This is false under normal conditions. Schlemm's canal contains aqueous humor, not blood. However, in certain pathological conditions or after certain surgical procedures, red blood cells can enter Schlemm's canal, but this is not a normal occurrence.

 

Schlemm’s Canal is:

 

  • An endothelium-lined oval venous sinus, sometimes broken into more than 1 lumen.
  • Present in the scleral sulcus.
  • A passage for drainage of the aqueous humor.


 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Contains aqueous: This is true. Schlemm's canal is a crucial component of the eye's drainage system, carrying the aqueous humor from the anterior chamber through the trabecular meshwork and into the canal.

 

Option C. Is lined by endothelium: True. Schlemm's canal is lined by a specialized endothelium, which plays a role in the regulation of aqueous humor outflow and intraocular pressure.

 

Option D. Contains partitions: True. Schlemm's canal contains trabecular beams and septae, which can be described as partitions within the canal. These structures can influence the flow of aqueous humor through the canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schlemm's canal is an endothelium-lined structure in the eye that contains aqueous humor and has internal partitions, but it does not normally contain red blood cells. Its primary function is in the drainage of aqueous humor, playing a key role in intraocular pressure regulation.

 

Ref: pg 77/ Anatomy & physiology of eyeball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Maintenance of Intra Ocular Pressure
To supply Glucose & Oxygen to Cornea
Provide Optical Clarity
All the above

questions.text: The Function(s) of Aqueous Humour is/are?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Explanation:

 

Functions of Aqueous Humour:

 

  1. Maintenance of Intra Ocular Pressure.
  2. Provide Nutrients and Oxygen.
  3. Remove Waste Products.
  4. Provide Optical Clarity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Function of Aqueous Humour is to maintain intraocular pressure and nourish cornea and maintain optical clarity.

 

 

Ref: pg 77/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Trabecular Meshwork
Schwalbe’s Line
Scleral Spur
Ciliary Body Band

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents to the emergency room with sudden severe eye pain, nausea, and blurred vision in her right eye. On examination, a shallow anterior chamber is noted. On gonioscopy, only the anterior-most structure in the angle of anterior chamber is visible, indicating it to be very narrow. Which is the structure the ophthalmologist must have seen on gonioscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schwalbe’s Line

 

Option B: This is the anterior most visible structure in gonioscopy. Schwalbe's line represents the termination of Descemet's membrane and the transition to the trabecular meshwork. It's often seen as a clear line or a slight ridge.

 

 

Angle structures from anterior to posterior:

  • Schwalbe’s line
  • Trabecular meshwork
  • Scleral spur
  • Ciliary body band

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Trabecular Meshwork is an important structure in the drainage of aqueous humor from the eye. It is posterior to the Schwalbe’s line.

 

Option C. Scleral Spur is located posterior to the trabecular meshwork. It is an important anatomical landmark in gonioscopy but is not the anteriormost structure.

 

Option D. The ciliary body band is a part of the ciliary body and is visible in gonioscopy, but it is located more posteriorly compared to Schwalbe's line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In gonioscopy, the anterior most structure visible is Schwalbe’s line, marking the transition from the cornea to the trabecular meshwork.

 

 

Ref: pg 73/ anatomy & physiology of eyeball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: 3.5
5.5
2.5
1.5

questions.text: A 32-year-old female came for a routine eye check-up and was found to have increased intraocular pressure in both the eyes. An increase in aqueous humour production or decrease in outflow leads to increased intraocular pressure. What is the normal rate of aqueous humour production (in microlitres/min)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2.5

 

Explanation:

 

The rate of aqueous humour production in a normal eye is approximately 2.5 microliters per minute.

 

 

Ref: pg. 84/ anatomy & physiology of eyeball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Blue on Yellow Perimetry
Red on Green
Black on White
White on White

questions.text: SWAP-Short Wavelength Automated Perimetry (SWAP), can detect early visual field loss in glaucoma using which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blue on Yellow Perimetry

 

Option A:

 

  • Blue-on-Yellow Perimetry (B-Y), also known as Short Wavelength Automated Perimetry (SWAP), detects early visual field loss before a reduction in differential light sensitivity is seen with standard white-on-white (W-W) perimetry in glaucoma.
  • It detects glaucomatous retinal ganglion cell death/dysfunction (sensitive to blue light) earlier than W-W perimeter, which tests all retinal ganglion cell populations.
  • The blue light is chosen because the eye's blue-sensitive photoreceptors (short-wavelength cones) are more susceptible to damage from glaucoma in the early stages. The yellow background helps to suppress the responses of the red and green cones, making the test more sensitive to the functioning of the blue cones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Red on green: This is not the method used in SWAP. Red on green perimetry is not specifically designed for early glaucoma detection and does not target the blue-sensitive photoreceptors.

 

Option C. Black on white: This describes standard achromatic perimetry, which is the conventional method used in many visual field tests. While useful for detecting glaucomatous damage, it is not as sensitive as SWAP in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option D. White on white: Like black on white, this is another form of standard achromatic perimetry. It's commonly used in routine visual field testing but does not have the same early detection capability for glaucoma as SWAP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Short Wavelength Automated Perimetry (SWAP) detects early glaucomatous damage by using a blue stimulus on a yellow background. This method targets the blue-sensitive photoreceptors, which are more vulnerable to early glaucomatous damage.

 

Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Blue_on_Yellow_Perimetry

choices.text: 2 cm
3 cm
2.5 mm
3.5 mm

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with intermittent blurry vision and pain in her left eye. Clinical examination reveals a narrow anterior chamber in the left eye and elevated intraocular pressure. What is the normal depth of anterior chamber at the centre?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2.5 MM

 

Explanation:

 

  • The depth of anterior chamber is = 2.5 – 3 .00 mm.
  • Contains 0.25 ml of aqueous humour.
  • Deeper in myopes.
  • Shallow in hypermetropia.

 

Ref: Pg 5/Anatomy & Physiology of Eye Ball /3rd Edition/AK KHURANA; Feng MT, Belin MW, Ambrósio R Jr, Grewal SP, Yan W, Shaheen MS, McGhee C, Maeda N, Neuhann TH, Burkhard Dick H, Alageel SA, Steinmueller A. Anterior chamber depth in normal subjects by rotating scheimpflug imaging. Saudi J Ophthalmol. 2011 Jul; 25(3):255-9. doi: 10.1016/j.sjopt.2011.04.005. Epub 2011 Apr 30. PMID: 23960933; PMCID: PMC3729361.
